What Did Early Canadian Women Eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Jennie E. Cameron
Address 125 East Street
Birthplace Norway, Skagway County, Canada

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? North Bay, Ontario
Where had you been living before that? North Bay, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? The usual necessities—Bought more dried fruit than today—prunes, apricots, peaches and even dried plums. (The dried plums were very sour but had the flavor talked about)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Hodgson's Royal Household, Fine Rose, Best Yet
In what quantities did you buy it? 40 lbs. at a time, several hundred
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
How much did you use Graham flour? 20 lbs. every month
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? ______ What year? ______
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ______
What other grain products did you use? Grapenuts
Cornmeal? Yes, whole wheat? No, Farina? No
Other? Oatmeal, ground wheat & rolled
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? A neighbor grinder

Fried eggs was a meal standby on the homestead

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

It was a pleasure even with all the hardships to prepare meals in the early days. Things are too hard made for the housewife today—and they do not seem to have any more time than we had to relax and enjoy a social life. The people of old days did have a chance, I call it "Happiness." Sometimes not knowing what they are hurrying or where they are going, the housewife of today hurries too much with the meals—a food in stores to buy—put up instead of ready to use—therefore, plenty of work to do.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In the late 20's and early 30's I began to rely on purchased and prepared foods. In the beginning, I offered outside the housewife to buy. For instance, the premium on breakfast foods would be a pretty high—and who would at fall for me? So the old fashioned healthy oat meal lasted a long time. I am right now reminded of the old Dutch proverb: "When fools go to market, peddlers make money."

I remember taking 6 day eggs to our little general store one hot summer day in 1908 and buying 1 day lemon with the price of the eggs.

Later:

One lady in Elmo has told me one better than the above. She took 6 day eggs to Elmo merchant and got 6 oranges with the price.

A Remembrance from Mrs. Edith Epp to Miss

Margaret Sherrill

Dear Miss Sherrill,

I am writing this letter to you because I have always been interested in your life and your experiences. You have always been a role model for me, and I admire your strength and resilience.

I remember when we were young girls, we would often go to the park together and play. We would spend hours there, laughing and having fun. It was during those times that I realized how much I admired you.

You were always so kind and generous, and I knew that I could always count on you. Even though we haven't seen each other in years, I still feel connected to you.

Thank you for being such an inspiration to me. I hope that our paths will cross again someday.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Miss Sherrill
With all the ups & downs of homestead life, we had our laughs too. One of the early homesteaders or pioneers was telling his wife after he had called on one of the neighboring homestead housewives.

The kind of dress she had on—

"It was a skirt," he said, "with 'Purity' printed on the front, and 'Five Roses' printed on the back." Her skirt was made of flour sacks.

J.E.C.

Although above as not in tune with the Questionnaire, I wanted to tell you the little story anyway.
